name: Non-Fiction Classics Online Quiz | Non-Fiction | 10 Questions

questions.text: 'The Communist Manifesto' was one of the principal works of the modern world. Karl Marx was the primary author; who was his co-author?
questions.explanation:
Friedrich Engels.

	Marx is the name that always leaps to mind.

questions.text: Along the same theme, who was the author of 'Das Kapital'?
'The Federalist Papers' were influential essays that were written during the revolutionary period in America. Who was NOT a main contributor to them?
questions.explanation:
Thomas Jefferson.

	Jefferson did just about everything else.

questions.text: This scientist-philosopher was highly controversial for his theories, as expressed in books such as 'Worlds in Collision'.
questions.explanation:
Immanuel Velikovsky.

	He may have been ahead of his time - although he may still be wrong.

questions.text: 'The Critique of Pure Reason' was considered a milestone in philosophical thought. Who wrote it?
questions.explanation:
Immanuel Kant.

	Kant. Over my head.

questions.text: Many writers known as 'muckrakers' exposed social evils. Which author was NOT one of them?
questions.explanation:
James M. Cain

	Sinclair's 'The Jungle' is perhaps the most well-known, followed by Tarbell's work on Standard Oil. Cain was a novelist.

questions.text: 'Candide' was a caustic lampoon of the notion that this was 'the best of all possible worlds'. Who wrote it?
questions.explanation:
Voltaire.

	Amusing, yet pointed. While technically this is a piece of fiction, it is also a platform for presenting a philosophical stance.

questions.text: It is perhaps a stretch to mention the 'Rosetta Stone' here: that was not significant for its content. Nevertheless, it was important because it provided a key to understanding languages. Who was primarily responsible for its interpretation and translation?
'All Gaul is divided into three parts ...'
questions.explanation:
Julius Caesar.

	'I came, I saw, I conquered'

questions.text: Many consider this man's work, 'Democracy in America', to be insightful and astute.
questions.explanation:
De Tocqueville.

	Early observations on the new republic
